2023.author: Jim Butcher
2023.title: Death Masks
2023.review: I don't know if vampires are just not my thing, but the duel with Ortega didn't captivate me enough to fully buy into this instalment of the Dresden Files.

2023.author: William R. Forstchen
2023.title: One Second After
2023.review: The intriguing premise and thought-provoking challenges faced by the protagonists make for an engaging narrative, but Forstchen struggles to craft truly believable characters and authentic dialogue.

2023.author: James S.A. Corey
2023.title: Nemesis Games
2023.review: The decision to split the Rocinante's crew and follow their individual paths, especially Amos' visit to Earth and the wonderfully disfunctional relationship between Filip and his father, initially gave me pause, but paid off immensely, especially with the nail-biter of the protomolecule coup.

2023.author: Chris Voss
2023.title: Never Split the Difference
2023.review: While I might raise the criticism of the book being a bit wordy at times, and Voss' examples a bit too extreme for the everyday negotiator, Never Split the Difference became an invaluable tool in a salary negotiation which ended up giving me the highest raise of my life.

2023.author: Perry Klebahn
2023.title: Ideaflow
2023.review: Ideaflow is the prime example of a non-fiction book that is not devoid of interesting insights, but could have communicated the same concepts on about a quarter of the length.

2023.author: Various Authors
2023.title: Poems for a World Gone to Shit
2023.review: While some of the included poems either delighted me or encouraged me to think, I closed the book and immediately forgot most of them.

2023.author: James S.A. Corey
2023.title: Babylon's Ashes
2023.review: I enjoyed every single minute of Babylon's Ashes, even though it is my least favorite Expanse book I read so far, not least because of the utter two-dimensionality of Marco Inaros as an antagonist.

2023.author: Jim Butcher
2023.title: Blood Rites
2023.review: I got the vague feeling that Butcher wanted to set one of the Dresden novels in the adult entertainment milieu for *ages* and finally gathered up the courage to do so, but I have to concede it resulted in one of the most entertaining and action-packed stories about the Chicago wizard, owed in great parts to the interesting concept of the White Court and the action movie stereotype that is Kincaid.
